data.title: Accessing files on network drives is slow
data.body:
Reported via Halp:
- support/6290a694aa0611e38d8242e11b72b07d

> Accessing files on network drives appears to be much slower than Sublime for the same mount & file. Additionally, the "Keep Waiting" decision box pops up almost every time.

I don't have a network drive, so I didn't verify this. :car: 

Edit: more reports:
- support/4e6fe392af5a11e38b62f01b0c57459b

data.title: Saving a file for which the user doesn't have write access to throws an exception in devtools
data.body:
Reported via Halp:

support/774b7918ae8611e3996cff0bee09ae91

> When try to save a file that I don't have the permissions, result in: Uncaught Error: EACCES, permission denied '/Volumes/igloo-data/Jobs/Royal Canin/Web Order/Mail template/HTML/weborder_mailing.html'

I managed to reproduce this by trying to save a file to the root folder, and clicking "Cancel" when the permission window popped up asking me for my password:

> Uncaught Error: EACCES, permission denied '/fds.txt' /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/pathwatcher/lib/file.js:153

data.title: Developer tools DOM selection overlay stays active even after devtools are closed
data.body:
Reported via Halp:
- support/963e4308ae5b11e39c0ca8abb6b96eb1

> when editing a random file, press option+command+I to open the webkit dev console, select a node in element view (eg. `<body>`), when the whole area is highlighted with the light blue fog, press option+command+I again to close the dev console, then the light blue fot remains, and there seems no way to dismiss it unless open the dev console again and diselect the node

I could reproduce this in Atom. Tried reproducing in Chrome, but couldn't -- Chrome behaves as expected.

data.title: Atom needs a better security model
data.body:
If we're going to add GitHub integration to Atom, we need to cache credentials inside the app. We had previously implemented GitHub auth for our Gists package, but we removed both the package and GitHub authentication from the beta release because we were afraid of providing GitHub credentials to every random Atom package people installed. We can't avoid this forever, though. To realize Atom's full potential, we need to solve the security issue in a robust way.
### What would the ideal security model look like?
- Every package is loaded in its own context.
- Every package's metadata includes a whitelist of the following:
  - Security-critical properties of the `atom` global requested by the package.
  - Security-critical built-in modules (such as `fs`) requested by the package.
  - Whether the package is allowed to load custom native modules.
  - GitHub permissions the package needs access to and any other credentials.
- When installing a package, the requested permissions are clearly presented.
- If a package attempts to reference or require a resource that isn't white-listed, the user will be explicitly prompted to grant the package that permission.
### How can we implement this?

There's a fairly mature project called [Google Caja](https://developers.google.com/caja/), whose goal is to allow multiple mutually-suspicious JavaScript modules to run on the same page securely. To support older versions of JavaScript, they employed a complex whole-program transformation to achieve this. But ES5 incorporates several standard features that allow a context to be secured by running a small JavaScript library called [SES](https://code.google.com/p/es-lab/wiki/SecureEcmaScript) (short for Secure ECMAScript).

My understanding is still evolving, but it seems like we should be able to run the SES script in a fresh context to tamper-proof any globals that we inject into it and secure them from malicious modification or any other kind of privilege escalation. To do this, we'd basically need to provide our own alternative module loading mechanism, which I  started experimenting with this weekend with a fork of Node's built-in `module.js`.
### What if we miss something?

Security is tough because you only have to screw up once to get exploited. We probably will make a few mistakes. But based on my reading about ES5 and the Caja project, security should be possible in theory. If we implement a security model that leaks, we can fix the problems as we discover them. But if we don't even try then things will never be secure. I think it's worth trying, then subjecting our best effort to an internal and possible external audit.
### What haven't I thought of?

This is all new territory for me. Let me know what I'm missing.

/cc @github/security @zcbenz @ptoomey3

data.title: Make Atom build on Linux
Enable automatic graphics switching
data.body:
Atom currently forces my Macbook Pro to use the discrete graphics card 100% of the time. This has a non-insubstantial impact on battery life, and probably isn't necessary for an editor.

This PR allows the app to use the integrated GPU, as per [Apple's docs](https://developer.apple.com/library/mac/qa/qa1734/_index.html)

Chromium itself also [sets this now](https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/chromium/+/trunk/chrome/app/app-Info.plist), so I can't see why we wouldn't.

data.title: Extract and improve Keymap
data.body:
- The Keymap's handling of multi-keystroke bindings needed to be overhauled due to atom/vim-mode#129. It now implements the algorithm I described there.
- In addition, if we're ever going to make jQuery optional it's imperative that our Keymap emit native DOM events rather than using jQuery's `.trigger` which won't call handlers registered with the native `.addEventListener` method.

I took the opportunity to address both these issues while extracting the Keymap to its own [npm](https://github.com/atom/atom-keymap) that we can open source. This was basically a ground-up rewrite that heavily borrowed from the previous implementation. Shims are in place so that the old keymap specs were green at the time of deletion.

There are a few methods that weren't appropriate to extract into a generic library for dealing with the built-in and user key bindings. As with the TextBuffer extraction, this is a bit awkward. I opted to add the to the Keymap prototype in `keymap-extensions.coffee`. Other ideas are welcome.

Remaining:
- [x] Iron out broken bindings via manual testing (not a ton of test coverage on key bindings)
- [x] Ensure documentation generates correctly
- [x] Update docs for Keymap class in atom-keymap module
- [x] Test going into pending states recursively

data.title: atom.workspaceView not available during deserialization
data.body:
This kind of bit me in the settings view, that view was listening on `pane-container:active-pane-item-changed` but if the view was being deserialized at startup then `atom.workspaceView` wouldn't be defined yet.

Not sure what we can do here but it is easy to make this mistake because you will only see this break if you reload Atom with your view open.

data.title: Respect leading whitespace when commenting empty lines
data.body:
support/7e04c220a7e511e399eceb141cced5cc#C3

We have a user who is using the comment command to start comments on empty lines. It's inserting the `#` character at the start of the line, rather than its current indentation level.

data.title: Don't show error messages for version and help cli options
data.body: This redirects stderr to /dev/null when the --help or --version arguments are used. It also shortens the help text so it fits within 80 chars.

data.title: Stop out of control mouse move listener
data.body:
https://bugsnag.com/atom/atom/errors/52c1da0783a277d9f7ed0eef

Closes #1755

data.title: Drag-selecting text to the top (over the tabs) throws errors when a different tab is clicked
data.body:
A bit hard to describe, so here's a gif based on a video [one of our users](support/9dc604c6aa9611e3844441d8f7c133b6?page=1) put together:

![error](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/38924/2409814/e5badabc-aab5-11e3-8af0-e384b68de5f4.gif)

Here's the error that's shown in console:

![screen shot 2014-03-13 at 2 48 30 pm](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/38924/2409843/4e3f255c-aab6-11e3-96a8-fcbd9e7c7f80.png)

data.title: Atom crashes on first run when cmd-shift-p is pressed while looking at the Welcome screen
data.body:
We've received a few reports from users about this:
- support/8b6a5a64a97611e38b24b62aa0f93f32
- support/9853bce2aa1711e38d61a10e88dcbbbb

So, it's the first time they started Atom, they were reading the Welcome page, and then pressed cmd-shift-p (which the Welcome page tells them is the most important thing). Also, my wife told me that the same thing happened to her on the first run (and only then).

I can't reproduce this by opening the Welcome page and pressing cmd-shift-p, so I'm guessing there's more to this than that. :confused:

data.title: Don't assume Atom is in /Applications when using the CLI
data.body:
It now looks in /Applications, ~/Applications, /Applications/Utilities, ~/Applications/Utilities/, and ~/Downloads

Sorta closes #1595

data.title: Example in SelectListView documentation doesn't work
data.body:
This example doesn't work. Confirm is never called. ``` # class MySelectListView extends SelectListView # initialize: -> # super # @addClass('overlay from-top') # @setItems(['Hello', 'World']) # atom.workspaceView.append(this) # @focusFilterEditor() # # viewForItem: (item) -> # "
  • #{item}
    • " # # confirmed: (item) -> # console.log("#{item} was selected") ``` via http://discuss.atom.io/t/selectlistview-confirmed-method-seems-never-called/4034/2

```

data.title: Dragging a file to the dock icon should open it
Problems with opening a file at a specific line
data.body:
Running `atom file.coffee:20` will open something.coffee at line 20. But if the editor already has file.coffee open, it will not scroll to line 20. This is causing problems for people wanting to create links from stacktraces.

/via http://discuss.atom.io/t/open-file-at-specific-line-and-column/3883/6

data.title: Upgrade to atom-shell@0.10.7
data.body:
Changelog:
- Make iframe sandboxed by default.
- Fix a crash caused when calling BrowserWindow.isWebViewFocused.

data.title: Send command to first responder when no window is focused
data.body: Fixes https://github.com/atom/atom-shell/issues/203 and fixes https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/1670 which is a duplicate.

data.title: Safe CSON during build
data.body:
A [cson parser](https://github.com/groupon/cson-safe) now exists so no more `CoffeeScript.eval` to "compile" CSON file.

This updates the `grunt-cson` version to one that uses the new parser.

data.title: Soft wrap config does not take effect immediately
data.body: Moved over from https://github.com/atom/settings-view/issues/47

data.title: Upgrade to underscore-plus@1.0.5
data.body: See: https://github.com/atom/underscore-plus/commit/31c7cb6d50922a5237523f1282f0607679eff563

data.title: ERB files default to HTML syntax highlighting
data.body: Atom appears to default to `HTML` syntax highlighting for docs labeled `filename.html.erb` instead of `HTML (Ruby - ERB)`, which of course is problematic because in regular HTML syntax highlighting embedded ruby variables are not highlighted correctly.
